title: 113_hr4289
content: The Act is titled the "Department of Homeland Security Interoperable Communications Act" or the "DHS Interoperable Communications Act." It includes interoperable communications capabilities in the responsibilities of the Under Secretary for Management. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include policies for achieving and maintaining interoperable communications among Department components. Interoperable communications are defined as the ability to exchange voice, data, and video in real time for various purposes. The Under Secretary for Management of the Department of Homeland Security must submit a strategy for achieving and maintaining interoperable communications among department components within 120 days of the enactment of this Act. The strategy should include an assessment of interoperability gaps in radio communications among the components. The Under Secretary for Management of the Department of Homeland Security must submit a strategy within 120 days of the enactment of this Act. The strategy should include information on efforts, obstacles, mechanisms, and guidance for achieving and maintaining interoperable communications among department components. The Under Secretary for Management of the Department of Homeland Security must submit a strategy within 120 days of the enactment of this Act, including guidance for implementing interoperable communications policies, total funds expended, projected future expenditures, dates for achieving department-wide interoperability for voice, data, and video communications, and interim milestones. The Senate committee requests information on intra-agency efforts for achieving interoperable communications within the Department of Homeland Security, including responsible parties and implementation of policies by the Under Secretary. The Senate committee requests a report on achieving interoperable communications within the Department of Homeland Security. The Under Secretary for Management must provide biannual reports to the House and Senate committees on Homeland Security regarding the progress in implementing the strategy for achieving interoperable communications within the Department of Homeland Security. The report should include updates on interim milestones, policies, directives, guidance, training, compliance levels, adoption, and participation among the department's components. The Under Secretary for Management must report biannually to Congress on the progress of achieving interoperable communications within the Department of Homeland Security, including updates on policies, directives, guidance, training, and participation among components. Additionally, the report should include information on any additional resources or authorities needed by the Under Secretary. The House of Representatives passed the document on July 8, 2014, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
